articles.headline: Higher Rates Stoke a Growing Chorus of Deficit Concerns
articles.snippet: A long period of higher interest rates would make the government’s large debt pile costly, a possibility that is fueling a conversation about debt sustainability.
articles.abstract: A long period of higher interest rates would make the government’s large debt pile costly, a possibility that is fueling a conversation about debt sustainability.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. government’s persistent budget deficit and growing debts were low on Wall Street’s list of worries when interest rates were at rock bottom for years. But borrowing costs have risen so sharply that it is causing many investors and economists to fret that the United States’ big debt pile could prove less sustainable.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek, Jim Tankersley and Joe Rennison

articles.headline: Opposition to Ukraine Aid Becomes a Litmus Test for the Right
articles.snippet: The drama that has played out among House Republicans over the past week has highlighted a sharp decline in the party’s willingness to back continued aid for Kyiv’s fight against Russia.
articles.abstract: The drama that has played out among House Republicans over the past week has highlighted a sharp decline in the party’s willingness to back continued aid for Kyiv’s fight against Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Republican meltdown on Capitol Hill that toppled the speaker this week and left the House in chaos has also highlighted a sharp decline in G.O.P. support for continuing to send aid to Ukraine, and how opposition to helping Kyiv has become a litmus test for the right.

articles.headline: Gathering to Mourn the Dead, and Dying Themselves in an Explosion in Ukraine
articles.snippet: Ukrainian officials said a Russian strike had killed at least 51 people in a tiny village with no obvious military or industrial targets nearby.
articles.abstract: Ukrainian officials said a Russian strike had killed at least 51 people in a tiny village with no obvious military or industrial targets nearby.
articles.lead_paragraph: They came to mourn the dead, but in a split second of thunder and flying debris, more than 50 people who had gathered for a wake were themselves killed on Thursday when a giant explosion tore through a shop in a tiny Ukrainian village.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer, David Guttenfelder and Eric Nagourney

articles.headline: Strong U.S. Job Growth Shows Economy Is Defying Challenges
articles.snippet: Employers added 336,000 jobs in September, almost double what experts had forecast and the biggest gain since January. Markets welcomed the report.
articles.abstract: Employers added 336,000 jobs in September, almost double what experts had forecast and the biggest gain since January. Markets welcomed the report.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sign of continued economic stamina, American payrolls grew by 336,000 in September on a seasonally adjusted basis, the Labor Department said on Friday.

articles.headline: An N.B.A. Power Broker, Growing Up and Finding Peace
articles.snippet: In a new memoir, Rich Paul, known to many for his long association with LeBron James, details his difficult upbringing and the valuable lessons it taught him.
articles.abstract: In a new memoir, Rich Paul, known to many for his long association with LeBron James, details his difficult upbringing and the valuable lessons it taught him.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Rich Paul considers his life now, he sometimes thinks how far it seems from his childhood, growing up Black in a particularly dangerous part of Cleveland.

articles.headline: Hiring Is Rising Along With Rates. Are They on a Collision Course?
articles.snippet: A run-up in longer-term interest rates could help the Federal Reserve get the economic cool-down it wants — but it also risks a bumpy landing.
articles.abstract: A run-up in longer-term interest rates could help the Federal Reserve get the economic cool-down it wants — but it also risks a bumpy landing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Heather Mahmood-Corley, a real estate agent, was seeing decent demand for houses in the Phoenix area just a few weeks ago. But as mortgage rates pick up again, she is already watching would-be home buyers retrench.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Joe Rennison
